description.en: After presenting the philosophical background of critical theory, the course will examine two key texts: The Dialectic of Enlightenment by Max Horkheimer and Theodor Adorno (1944) and One-Dimensional Man by Herbert Marcuse (1964). Next the issue of culture and cultural criticism will be discussed in selected essays of Walter Benjamin and Theodor Adorno. The course concludes with the work of Jürgen Habermas, Judith Butler, and Didier Fassin.
description.et: Pärast tutvumist kriitilise teooria filosoofilise taustaga, keskendutakse kahele põhitekstile: Max Horkheimeri ja Theodor Adorno 'The Dialectic of Enlightenment' (1944) ning Herbert Marcuse 'One-Dimensional Man' (1964). Järgmiseks vaadeldakse kultuuri ja kultuurikriitika küsimusi Walter Benjamini ja Theodor Adorno valitud esseedes. Lõpetuseks loetakse ja arutatakse Jürgen Habermasi, Judith Butler ja Didier Fassin kirjutisi.

objectives.en: The objective of the course is to familiarize students with contemporary texts of political philosophy
objectives.et: Aine eesmärk on tutvustada üliõpilastele tänapäeva poliitikafilosoofia tekste.

learning_outcomes.en:
The learning outcomes are a firm understanding of contemporary texts of political and social philosophy. Having passed the course, the student has also improved his or her ability to analyze philosophical texts, his or her presentations skills.

Students will also develop the following skills:

Self-Management Skills - time management, goal setting and self-motivation.

Academic skills - reading academic texts, academic writing and critical thinking.

People skills - how to communicate and participate in team work.

These will be developed during the seminar with group work and include skills for debating and for writing a well structured paper in philosophy.
learning_outcomes.et: Aine läbinud üliõpilasel on selge arusaam tänapäeva poliitika- ja sotsiaalfilosoofilia alastest kirjutistest. Ta on ka arendanud oma filosoofilise teksti analüüsimise oskust ning esitlusoskusi.

notes.et: The Frankfurt School represents a group of German intellectuals who formed the Institute for Social Research in 1930. With the rise of Hitler to power, the Institute moved to New York and later to California. Some stayed in the United States, while others returned to Frankfurt in 1950. The work of the Frankfurt School while varied and interdisciplinary, centered around a critique of the Enlightenment and mass culture as distinctively modern. During the course, our discussions will focus on the importance of radio and film, the influence of National Socialism on mass society, and the negative aspects of Western reason and rationality.

independent_work.et: Students are required to read the texts at home, to prepare the presentation, and to write two essays.

grade_evaluation.et:

description.et:
The reading group meets once a week for 14 weeks.

1	Introduction: Philosophical Roots of Critical Theory in Kant, Marx, Weber, Nietzsche, Freud; Horkheimer & Adorno: Dialectic of Enlightenment, 	“The Concept of Enlightenment”

2 	Adorno & Horkheimer: Dialectic of Enlightenment, “The Culture Industry" 

3-4	Adorno et al., selections from The Authoritarian Personality, intro, ch 1, 7, 9

5	Benjamin: “Work of Art in an Age of Mechanical Reproduction” from Illuminations

6	Benjamin: “Theses on Philosophy of History” from Illuminations

7-8	Marcuse: selections from One Dimensional Man, chapters 1-2, 7-10
	
9-10 Habermas: Intro and ch 4 The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere
	
11-12	Butler: Adorno Prize & selections from Frames of Mourning 

13-14	Fassin, Adorno lectures: selections from Life: a critical user’s manual

audience.et: MA, PhD, and last year BA students in philosophy and related fields
